vulnerability_findings.name: use-ownable2step
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: contract Haltable is Ownable {
vulnerability_findings.message: By demanding that the receiver of the owner permissions actively accept via a contract call of its own,  `Ownable2Step` and `Ownable2StepUpgradeable` prevent the contract ownership from accidentally being transferred  to an address that cannot handle it.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-ownable2step
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: contract ReleasableToken is StandardToken, Ownable {
vulnerability_findings.message: By demanding that the receiver of the owner permissions actively accept via a contract call of its own,  `Ownable2Step` and `Ownable2StepUpgradeable` prevent the contract ownership from accidentally being transferred  to an address that cannot handle it.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-ownable2step
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: contract MintableToken is Mintable, Ownable {
vulnerability_findings.message: By demanding that the receiver of the owner permissions actively accept via a contract call of its own,  `Ownable2Step` and `Ownable2StepUpgradeable` prevent the contract ownership from accidentally being transferred  to an address that cannot handle it.

vulnerability_findings.name: init-variables-with-default-value
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: bool public released = false;
vulnerability_findings.message: Uninitialized variables are assigned with the types default value. Explicitly initializing a variable with its default value costs unnecessary gas.

vulnerability_findings.message: Uninitialized variables are assigned with the types default value. Explicitly initializing a variable with its default value costs unnecessary gas.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(start != 0 && end != 0);
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(block.timestamp < start && start < end);
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-nested-if
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: else if (block.timestamp <= endsAt && !isCrowdsaleFull()) return State.Funding;
vulnerability_findings.message: Using nested is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-nested-if
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: else return State.Success;
vulnerability_findings.message: Using nested is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-prefix-increment-not-postfix
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: investorCount++;
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using the prefix increment expression whenever the return value is not needed. The prefix increment expression is cheaper in terms of gas.

vulnerability_findings.name: uninitialized-state
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: CrowdsaleToken public token;
vulnerability_findings.message:
GenericCrowdsale.token (GenericCrowdsale.sol#849) is never initialized. It is used in:
	- preallocate (GenericCrowdsale.sol#993-999)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in UpgradeableToken.upgrade (GenericCrowdsale.sol#563-579):
	External calls:
	- upgradeAgent.upgradeFrom(msg.sender,value) (GenericCrowdsale.sol#572)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- totalUpgraded (GenericCrowdsale.sol#576)

vulnerability_findings.name: unused-return
vulnerability_findings.message:
LostAndFoundToken.enableLostAndFound (GenericCrowdsale.sol#665-670) does not use the value returned by external calls:
	-token_contract.approve(agent,tokens) (GenericCrowdsale.sol#669)

vulnerability_findings.name: shadowing-local
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: uint allowance = allowed[from][msg.sender];
vulnerability_findings.message:
StandardToken.transferFrom.allowance (local variable @ GenericCrowdsale.sol#269) shadows:
	- StandardToken.allowance (function @ GenericCrowdsale.sol#306-308)
	- EIP20Token.allowance (function @ GenericCrowdsale.sol#161)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-benign
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in GenericCrowdsale.preallocate (GenericCrowdsale.sol#993-999):
	External calls:
	- tokenAmount = fullTokens.mul(10 ** uint256(token.decimals())) (GenericCrowdsale.sol#995)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- investedAmountOf (GenericCrowdsale.sol#998)
	- tokenAmountOf (GenericCrowdsale.sol#998)
	- tokensSold (GenericCrowdsale.sol#998)
	- weiRaised (GenericCrowdsale.sol#998)

vulnerability_findings.name: timestamp
vulnerability_findings.message:
GenericCrowdsale.GenericCrowdsale (GenericCrowdsale.sol#922-930) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- require(bool)(block.timestamp < start && start < end) (GenericCrowdsale.sol#927)

vulnerability_findings.name: timestamp
vulnerability_findings.message:
GenericCrowdsale.getState (GenericCrowdsale.sol#1103-1108) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- block.timestamp < startsAt (GenericCrowdsale.sol#1105-1107)
	- block.timestamp <= endsAt && ! isCrowdsaleFull() (GenericCrowdsale.sol#1106-1107)

vulnerability_findings.name: constable-states
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: string public name = "WorldBit Token";
vulnerability_findings.message:
CrowdsaleToken.name should be constant (GenericCrowdsale.sol#770)
CrowdsaleToken.symbol should be constant (GenericCrowdsale.sol#772)
UpgradeAgent.originalSupply should be constant (GenericCrowdsale.sol#476)
